items.name: AD_ACCOUNT_PREFIX
items.description: Prefix used in names while creating accounts in Active Directory. The prefix can be up to 10 characters long and can be set to identify accounts used for authentication by CDH processes. Used only if Active Directory KDC is used for authentication.

items.name: AD_ACCOUNT_PROPERTIES
items.description: Active Directory account properties used in credential generation. Used only if Active Directory KDC is being used for authentication.

items.name: AD_DELETE_ON_REGENERATE
items.displayName: Active Directory Delete Accounts on Credential Regeneration
items.description: Set this option to true if regeneration of credentials should automatically delete the associated Active Directory accounts. Used only if Active Directory KDC is used for authentication.

items.name: AD_KDC_DOMAIN
items.description: Active Directory suffix where all the accounts used by CDH daemons will be created. Used only if Active Directory KDC is being used for authentication.

items.name: AD_LDAPS_PORT
items.description: Port to use for LDAP over TLS/SSL when using Active Directory for authentication.

items.name: AD_PASSWORD_PROPERTIES
items.description: Active Directory password properties used in password generation. Used only if Active Directory KDC is being used for authentication.

items.name: AD_SET_ENCRYPTION_TYPES
items.description: Set this option to true if creation of Active Directory accounts should automatically turn on the associated encryption types represented by the msDS-EncryptionTypes field. Used only if Active Directory KDC is used for authentication.

items.name: AGENT_PORT
items.displayName: Agent Port to connect to Server
items.description: Specify the port for Agents to use to connect to the Server. Must be 1024 or higher.

items.name: AGENT_TLS
items.description: Select this option to enable TLS encryption between the Server and Agents.

items.name: AGGREGATOR_METRICS
items.description:
Specifies the set of metrics fetched periodically from each Cloudera Manager by the back end. Metrics defined here are available for inclusion in Multi Cloudera Manager Dashboard profiles, which are used to configure which information is available on the dashboard.

Each metric has the following fields:

  • name (mandatory) - The name of the metric. This value must be unique across all metrics configured.
  • query (mandatory) - A tsquery expression representing the metric. The tsquery expression is issued against a remote Cloudera Manager. Queries defined in this section are expected to return a scalar value. Using a fucntion like 'last', 'min', or 'max' is recommended. See the tsquery documentation for more details on how to construct queries.

For example, the following metric could be defined to get CPU usage for all clusters from all Cloudera Manager intances. Cloudera supports fetching cluster level metrics by using 'clusterName = $CLUSTERNAME'. At runtime, the $CLUSTERNAME variable is substituted with the name of each cluster.

"name": "CPU Usage",
"query": "select last(cpu_percent_across_hosts) where category = CLUSTER and clusterName = $CLUSTERNAME"

items.name: ALLOW_USAGE_DATA
items.description: Allows Cloudera to collect usage data, including the use of Google Analytics.

items.name: AUTH_BACKEND_ORDER
items.description: The order in which authentication back ends are used for authenticating a user. Emergency Administrator Access allows Full and User Administrators in the local database to authenticate if external authentication is not functioning.

items.name: AUTH_SCRIPT
items.description: An external script (or binary) to use to authenticate users. Username is passed as the first command line argument. The password is passed over stdin. Program exit code should be 0 for successful authentication of a Read-Only user, 1 for successful authentication of a Full Administrator user, 2 for successful authentication of a Limited Operator user, 3 for successful authentication of an Operator user, 4 for successful authentication of a Configurator user, 5 for successful authentication of a Cluster Administrator user, 6 for successful authentication of a BDR Administrator user, 7 for successful authentication of a Navigator Administrator user, 8 for successful authentication of a User Administrator user, 9 for successful authentication of an Auditor user, 10 for successful authentication of a Key Administrator user, and a negative value for failure. A failure description can be printed to stderr.

items.name: BDR_REPLICATION_KERBEROS_KEYTAB_LOCATION
items.displayName: Custom Kerberos Keytab Location (to be used for replication for secure clusters on this Cloudera Manager)
items.description: Define a custom Kerberos keytab location on the Cloudera Manager host to use for replication. If this configuration is specified, the "Custom Kerberos Principal Name" must also be specified. The keytab should be owned by the user running the Cloudera Manager server process (typically "cloudera-scm") and should be configured with a filesystem access control of "0400".

items.name: BDR_REPLICATION_KERBEROS_PRINCIPAL_NAME
items.displayName: Custom Kerberos Principal Name (to be used for replication for secure clusters on this Cloudera Manager)
items.description: Define a custom Kerberos principal name with an entry in the custom keytab defined in "Custom Kerberos Keytab Location". The principal should be a fully qualified name of an existing principal (eg. adminuser@MY.COMPANY.COM) and the principal must have an entry in the keytab specified in "Custom Kerberos Keytab Location". The principal should also be a superuser in all distributed file system services on secure clusters in this Cloudera Manager.

items.name: CLIENT_CONFIG_AUTH
items.displayName: Require Authentication to Download Client Configurations
items.description: When enabled, downloading client configurations through the API or through the URLs displayed in the UI requires normal authentication. When disabled, no authentication is required.

items.name: CLUSTER_STATS_COUNT
items.displayName: Number of Diagnostic Bundles to Keep
items.description: The maximum number of command results to keep before deleting them from local storage. This property is used for the commands that generate large result files. A value of -1 indicates no limit.

items.name: CLUSTER_STATS_DEFAULT_SIZE_MB
items.description: Approximate size in MB of scheduled diagnostic data bundle

items.name: CLUSTER_STATS_HTTP
items.displayName: Use HTTPS to Upload Diagnostic Data
items.description: Whether to use HTTPS to upload diagnostic data bundles instead of the now-deprecated SFTP. Uses proxy settings from the network setting.

items.name: CLUSTER_STATS_PATH
items.description: Local directory to store diagnostic data bundles. Leave blank to store bundles for 24 hours. This directory must be writable by the cloudera-scm user.

items.name: CLUSTER_STATS_SCHEDULE
items.description: Frequency of automatically collecting diagnostic data and sending to Cloudera support.

items.name: CLUSTER_STATS_START
items.description: Time of day to collect and send diagnostic data to Cloudera

items.name: CLUSTER_STATS_TMP_PATH
items.description: Local path to assemble diagnostic data bundles. Leave blank to assemble these bundles in your JVM temp directory. Set this value if you run out of disk space while collecting diagnostic data.

items.name: CM_HOST_NAME
items.description: Override to use for Cloudera Manager's hostname. Normally this is determined automatically, but this can be used if InetAddress.getLocalhost() is returning the loopback address.

items.name: COMMAND_EVICTION_AGE_HOURS
items.description: Length of time after which inactive commands are evicted from the database. Default is two years.

items.name: COMMAND_STORAGE_PATH
items.displayName: Cloudera Manager Server Local Data Storage Directory
items.description: Local path used by Cloudera Manager for storing data, including command result files. Note that changes to this configuration will only apply to commands started after the change. It is highly recommended that existing data be migrated over to the new location for the data to be accessible via and managed by Cloudera Manager.

items.name: CROSS_ENTITY_AGGREGATE_FILTERS
items.description:
Specifies two filters, a blacklist and a whitelist, that impact cross-entity aggregates generated by the Cloudera Manager monitoring system. By default, cross-entity aggregates are generated for all types. The blacklist entries can be used to disable generation of cross-entity aggregates, and whitelist entries can be used to force their creation.

The JSON structure of this field is as follows:

  • blacklist - A filter that when matched will prevent cross-entity aggregate creation. The structure of the filter is outlined below.
  • whitelist - A filter that when matched will force cross-entity aggregate creation. The structure of the filter is outlined below. This filter takes precedence over the blacklist filter, so if both are matched, an aggregate will be generated.

The JSON structure of either filter is as follows:

  • types - A list of entries in the following format sourceType::targetType::aggregateMetricType, e.g. DATANODE::RACK::STATISTICAL.
  • streams - A list of entries in the following format sourceType::targetType::metricName::aggregateMetricType, e.g. HOST::CLUSTER::fd_open::TOTAL.

In the above filters the source and target types are entity type strings used within the metric system. ROLE, SERVICE and ALL are wildcards that match all role types, service types and all types respectively. Metrics are referred to by their user facing names, so counter-based metrics will be in _rate form. The two types of aggregate metrics are TOTAL and STATISTICAL.

After making changes to this field, both the Cloudera Manager Server and the Service and Host Monitors should be restarted.

For advanced use only. You could break Cloudera Manager charting and health functionality by editing this field.

items.name: CSD_REPO_ENABLED
items.description: When enabled, the server will read custom service descriptors from the local filesystem.

items.name: CSD_REPO_PATH
items.description: Path to the local repository where custom service descriptors are located.

items.name: CUSTOM_BANNER_HTML
items.description: The custom banner is used to display a customer specific text in the header area.

items.name: CUSTOM_HEADER_COLOR
items.description: The custom header color is used to distinguish different instances of Cloudera Manager.

items.name: CUSTOM_IA_POLICY
items.description: An information assurance policy statement that must be agreed to in order for a user to login.

items.name: DIAG_BUNDLE_REDACTION_POLICY
items.description:
Note: Do not edit this property in the classic layout. Switch to the new layout to edit and test your rules inline.

Use this property to define a list of rules to be followed for redacting sensitive information from diagnostic bundles. Click + to add a new redaction rule. You can choose one of the preconfigured rules or add a custom rule. When specifying a custom rule, the Search field should contain a regular expression to be matched against the data. If a match is found, it is replaced by the contents of the Replace field.

Trigger is an optional field. It can be used to specify a simple string to be searched in the data. If the string is found, the redactor attempts to find a match for the Search regex. If no trigger is specified, redaction occurs by matching the Search regular expression. Use the Trigger field to enhance performance: simple string matching is faster than regular expression matching.

Test your rules by entering sample text into the Test Redaction Rules text box and clicking Test Redaction. If no rules match, the text you entered is returned unchanged.

items.name: DISTRIBUTE_PARCELS_AUTOMATICALLY
items.description: Whether available parcels should be automatically distributed to any cluster that already has parcels of the same product.

items.name: DOWNLOAD_PARCELS_AUTOMATICALLY
items.description: Whether new parcels discovered on the remote parcel repository should be automatically downloaded.

items.name: ENABLE_AGGREGATOR
items.description: Allows this Cloudera Manager to periodically collect and aggregate health and status data from other Cloudera Manager instances. Go to Multi Cloudera Manager Dashboard.

items.name: ENABLE_API_DEBUG
items.description: When enabled, the server log will contain traces of all API calls.

items.name: ENABLE_EMBEDDED_DB_CHECK
items.description: When this option is unchecked, warnings about the embedded PostgreSQL database are suppressed.

items.name: EVENTS_WIDGET_SEARCH_ON_LOAD
items.description: When enabled, the Events widget at the bottom of many pages will auto-fire its default search on page load.

items.name: GEN_KEYTAB_SCRIPT
items.description: Specify the path to a custom script (or executable) to retrieve a Kerberos keytab. The script should take two arguments: a destination file to write the keytab to, and the full principal name to retrieve the key for. If this property is specified, Cloudera Manager ignores all other properties specified for Kerberos setup.

items.name: HEARTBEAT_INTERVAL
items.description: The interval between each heartbeat that is sent from Agents to the server

items.name: HEARTBEAT_LOGGING_DIR
items.description: Specifies the location where Agent heartbeat requests and responses should be logged, for debugging purposes. If empty, logging is disabled.

items.name: HOME_PAGE_FULL_LIMIT
items.displayName: Maximum Cluster Count Shown In Full
items.description: When the number of clusters exceeds this number, only the cluster summary information will be shown on the home page.

items.name: HTTP_PORT
items.description: Specify the HTTP port to use to access the Server via the Admin Console. Must be 1024 or higher.

items.name: HTTPS_PORT
items.description: Specify the HTTPS port to use to access the Server via the Admin Console. Must be 1024 or higher.

items.name: KDC_ACCOUNT_CREATION_HOST_OVERRIDE
items.description: If multiple Active Directory Domain Controllers are behind a load-balancer, Cloudera Manager should be provided with the address of one of them. Cloudera Manager then sends commands to create accounts to that Domain Controller only. Note: This setting is used only while creating accounts. CDH services use the value entered in the KDC Server Host field only while authenticating.

items.name: KDC_ADMIN_HOST
items.description: Host where the KDC Admin server is located. Port number is optional and can be provided as hostname[:port]

items.name: KDC_HOST
items.description: Host where the KDC server is located. Port number is optional and can be provided as hostname[:port]

items.name: KDC_TYPE
items.description: Type of KDC used for authentication in CDH clusters

items.name: KEYSTORE_PASSWORD
items.displayName: Cloudera Manager TLS/SSL Server JKS Keystore File Password
items.description: The password for the Cloudera Manager JKS keystore file.

items.name: KEYSTORE_PATH
items.displayName: Cloudera Manager TLS/SSL Server JKS Keystore File Location
items.description: The path to the TLS/SSL keystore file containing the server certificate and private key used for TLS/SSL. Used when Cloudera Manager is acting as a TLS/SSL server. The keystore must be in JKS format.

items.name: KRB_DNS_LOOKUP_KDC
items.description: Indicate whether DNS SRV records should be used to locate the KDCs and other servers for a realm, if they are not listed in the krb5.conf information for the realm.

items.name: KRB_DOMAIN
items.description: Domain(s) which are mapped to this Kerberos Realm. This is used to generate [domain_realm] section. Also, the first domain is used as default_domain in [realms] section

items.name: KRB_ENC_TYPES
items.description: Encryption types supported by KDC. Note: To use AES encryption, make sure you have deployed JCE Unlimited Strength Policy File by following the instructions here.

items.name: KRB_FORWARDABLE
items.description: If this flag is true, initial tickets will be forwardable by default, if allowed by the KDC.

items.name: KRB_KDC_TIMEOUT
items.description: The maximum time to wait for a reply from the KDC. A time of 0 seconds means "use the client's default".

items.name: KRB_LIBDEFAULTS_SAFETY_VALVE
items.displayName: Advanced Configuration Snippet (Safety Valve) for [libdefaults] section of krb5.conf
items.description: For advanced use only. Any text here will be emitted verbatim in the [libdefaults] section of krb5.conf.

items.name: KRB_MANAGE_KRB5_CONF
items.description: Whether Cloudera Manager should configure and deploy krb5.conf on secure clusters. If this property is not checked, then you must ensure that krb5.conf is deployed on hosts in a secure cluster as well as on Cloudera Manager Server's host.

items.name: KRB_OTHER_SAFETY_VALVE
items.displayName: Advanced Configuration Snippet (Safety Valve) for remaining krb5.conf
items.description: For advanced use only. Cloudera Manager configures the [libdefaults], [realms] and [domain_realm] section of krb5.conf. Any text here will be emitted verbatim after them in krb5.conf.

items.name: KRB_REALMS_SAFETY_VALVE
items.displayName: Advanced Configuration Snippet (Safety Valve) for the Default Realm in krb5.conf
items.description: For advanced use only. Any text here will be emitted verbatim in the [realms] section of krb5.conf for the specified security realm. If you want to add realms besides the default one, configure them using Advanced Configuration Snippet (Safety Valve) for remaining krb5.conf.

items.name: KRB_RENEW_LIFETIME
items.description: Default renewable lifetime for initial ticket requests.

items.name: KRB_TICKET_LIFETIME
items.description: Default lifetime for initial ticket requests.

items.name: LDAP_ADMIN_GROUPS
items.description: A list of LDAP group names. If a user is a member of one of the configured groups, that user is granted Full admin access on login.

items.name: LDAP_AUDITOR_GROUPS
items.description: A list of LDAP group names. If a user is a member of one of the configured groups, that user is granted Auditor access on login.

items.name: LDAP_BDR_ADMIN_GROUPS
items.description: A list of LDAP group names. If a user is a member of one of the configured groups, that user is granted BDR admin access on login.

items.name: LDAP_BIND_DN
items.description: Distinguished name of the user to bind as. This is used to connect to LDAP/AD for searching user and group information. This may be left blank if the LDAP server supports anonymous binds.

items.name: LDAP_BIND_PW
items.description: The password of the bind user.

items.name: LDAP_CLUSTER_ADMIN_GROUPS
items.description: A list of LDAP group names. If a user is a member of one of the configured groups, that user is granted Cluster admin access on login.

items.name: LDAP_CONFIGURATOR_GROUPS
items.description: A list of LDAP group names. If a user is a member of one of the configured groups, that user is granted configurator access on login.

items.name: LDAP_DN_PATTERN
items.description: For use with non-Active Directory LDAP systems. This is a pattern that will be used to search for the distinguished name of a user during authentication. Use "{0}" to specify where the username should go, e.g. "uid={0},ou=People".

items.name: LDAP_GROUP_SEARCH_BASE
items.description: A base distinguished name for searching for groups.

items.name: LDAP_GROUP_SEARCH_FILTER
items.description: A search filter for finding groups. Typically, this will be (member={0}), where {0} will be replaced by the DN of a successfully authenticated user.

items.name: LDAP_KEY_ADMIN_GROUPS
items.description: A list of LDAP group names. If a user is a member of one of the configured groups, that user is granted Key Administrator access on login.

items.name: LDAP_LIMITED_GROUPS
items.description: A list of LDAP group names. If a user is a member of one of the configured groups, that user is granted limited operator access on login.

items.name: LDAP_NAVIGATOR_ADMIN_GROUPS
items.description: A list of LDAP group names. If a user is a member of one of the configured groups, that user is granted Navigator admin access on login.

items.name: LDAP_OPERATOR_GROUPS
items.description: A list of LDAP group names. If a user is a member of one of the configured groups, that user is granted operator access on login.

items.name: LDAP_TYPE
items.description: The type of external authentication to use.

items.name: LDAP_URL
items.description:
The URL of the LDAP server. The URL must be prefixed with ldap:// or ldaps://. The URL can optionally specify a custom port, for example: ldaps://ldap_server.example.com:1636. Note that usernames and passwords will be transmitted in the clear unless either an ldaps:// URL is used, or "Enable LDAP TLS" is turned on (where available). Also note that encryption must be in use between the client and this service for the same reason.

For more detail on the LDAP URL format, see RFC 2255 . A space-separated list of URLs can be entered; in this case the URLs will each be tried in turn until one replies.

items.name: LDAP_USER_ADMIN_GROUPS
items.description: A list of LDAP group names. If a user is a member of one of the configured groups, that user is granted User admin access on login.

items.name: LDAP_USER_GROUPS
items.description: A list of LDAP group names. If a user is not a member of one of the configured groups, that user is prevented from logging into Cloudera Manager. If this is left empty, all LDAP users can log in.

items.name: LDAP_USER_SEARCH_BASE
items.description: A base distinguished name for searching for users. This may be used as a fallback mechanism if the DN pattern does not match any user.

items.name: LDAP_USER_SEARCH_FILTER
items.description: A search filter for finding users. Typically, this will be (uid={0}), where {0} will be replaced by the username that was used at the login screen.

items.name: MANAGES_PARCELS
items.description: Whether Cloudera Manager should manage which parcels should be present on all managed hosts.

items.name: MAX_RENEW_LIFE
items.description: Maximum renewable lifetime for Kerberos principals generated by Cloudera Manager. This property is used only if MIT KDC is used. Set this property to zero if the KDC should provide the maximum renewable lifetime. Note: Principals with non-renewable tickets are not recommended because they can prevent Hadoop services from functioning.

items.name: MISSED_HB_BAD
items.displayName: Set health status to Bad if the Agent heartbeats fail
items.description: If an Agent fails to send this number of expected consecutive heartbeats to the Server, a "Bad" health status is assigned to that Agent.

items.name: MISSED_HB_CONCERNING
items.displayName: Set health status to Concerning if the Agent heartbeats fail
items.description: If an Agent fails to send this number of expected consecutive heartbeats to the Server, a "Concerning" health status is assigned to that Agent.

items.name: NEED_AGENT_HOSTNAME_VALIDATION
items.description: Select this option to verify that agent hostnames must match their TLS client certificates.

items.name: NEED_AGENT_VALIDATION
items.displayName: Use TLS Authentication of Agents to Server
items.description: Select this option to enable TLS Authentication of Agents to the Server.

items.name: NT_DOMAIN
items.description: This parameter is useful when authenticating against an Active Directory server. This value is appended to all usernames before authenticating against AD. For example, if this parameter is set to "my.domain.com", and the user authenticating is "mike", then "mike@my.domain.com" is passed to AD. If this field is unset, the username remains unaltered before being passed to AD.

items.name: PARCEL_AUTODOWNLOAD_PRODUCTS
items.description: If automatic parcel downloading is enabled, the list of products that will be downloaded.

items.name: PARCEL_CLEANUP_AUTOMATICALLY
items.description: Whether parcels for old versions of an activated product should be removed from a cluster when they are no longer in use.

items.name: PARCEL_CLEANUP_THRESHOLD
items.displayName: Number of Old Parcel Versions to Retain
items.description: If automatic removal of old parcels is enabled, the number of old parcels to keep. Any old parcels beyond this value will any be removed. If this is set to zero, no old parcels will be retained.

items.name: PARCEL_DISTRIBUTE_RATE_LIMIT_KBS_PER_SECOND
items.description: Per-second rate limit for parcel distribution.  The default of 50MiB/second allows for parcel distribution to saturate about half of a Gigabit link.

items.name: PARCEL_MAX_UPLOAD
items.description: Maximum number of concurrent uploads allowed to distribute parcels to individual hosts. The maximum allowed number of concurrent uploads is 50.

items.name: PARCEL_PROXY_PASSWORD
items.description: The basic authentication password for the proxy.

items.name: PARCEL_PROXY_PORT
items.description: The port for the proxy server to be used when the Cloudera Manager Server accesses the Internet, such as when downloading parcels and uploading diagnostic data.

items.name: PARCEL_PROXY_PROTOCOL
items.description: The protocol to use for the proxy server when the Cloudera Manager Server accesses the Internet, such as when downloading parcels and uploading diagnostic data.

items.name: PARCEL_PROXY_SERVER
items.description: The proxy server to be used when the Cloudera Manager Server accesses the Internet, such as when downloading parcels and uploading diagnostic data.

items.name: PARCEL_PROXY_USER
items.description: The basic authentication user name for the proxy.

items.name: PARCEL_RELATION_VALIDATION
items.description: Enforce that parcel dependencies are satisfied and conflicts are prevented when activating parcels. Parcel relations (Depends, Conflicts, and Replaces) can be defined the manifests of parcel repositories. Cloudera Manager can also enforce some default relations if none are defined in the manifest.

items.name: PARCEL_REPO_PATH
items.description: Path to the local package parcel repository from which binaries are served to the Agents.

items.name: PARCEL_SYMLINKS
items.displayName: Create System-Wide Symlinks for Active Parcels
items.description: Whether system-wide symlinks should be created for the active parcels (for example, /usr/bin/hadoop).

items.name: PARCEL_UPDATE_FREQ
items.description: How often to check local and remote parcel repositories for new parcels and if any old parcels should be cleaned up.

items.name: PARCEL_USERS_GROUPS_PERMISSIONS
items.displayName: Create Users and Groups, and Apply File Permissions for Parcels
items.description: Whether a parcel's specified users, groups and file permissions should be applied. This may not be desired if custom users and groups are being used, or if they have to be created externally (eg: in LDAP)

items.name: PHONE_HOME
items.displayName: Send Diagnostic Data to Cloudera Automatically
items.description: Allows the Server to automatically send diagnostic data when a collection is triggered.

items.name: REFERER_CHECK
items.description: Whether to verify "Referer" in HTTP header for state changing requests. This protects against cross-site request forgery, but may need to be turned off if browsers or proxies in your environment do not specify the header.

items.name: REMOTE_PARCEL_REPO_URLS
items.description: URLs of the remote parcel repositories where Cloudera Manager checks for new parcels. When checking for new parcels, Cloudera Manager sends the ID of the server and the server version to the repository host. The special variable {latest_supported} is replaced with the latest version of CDH that Cloudera Manager supports when checks are made.

items.name: REPORT_CONFIGURATIONS
items.description: List of configurations for the Cluster Utilization Report.

items.name: RETAIN_PARCELS_IN_CACHE
items.description: Whether downloaded parcel files be kept by Agents after they have been unpacked. Keeping the parcel files consumes additional disk space but allows downloads to be avoided if the parcel ever needs to be unpacked again.

items.name: SAML_ENTITY_ALIAS
items.description: Unique alias used to identify the selected instance of local service provider based on used URL.

items.name: SAML_ENTITY_BASE_URL
items.description: The Base URL used to construct redirect URLs reported in this server's SP metadata. Leave this blank to let the server calculate the base URL itself.

items.name: SAML_ENTITY_ID
items.description: The ID that Cloudera Manager will use to identify itself to the IDP. This value should be unique to this Cloudera Manager installation.

items.name: SAML_KEY_ALIAS
items.displayName: Alias of SAML Sign/Encrypt Private Key
items.description: The alias used to identify the sign/encrypt private key in the SAML keystore.

items.name: SAML_KEY_PASSWORD
items.description: The password for the sign/encrypt private key in the SAML keystore.

items.name: SAML_KEYSTORE_PASSWORD
items.description: The password for the SAML keystore.

items.name: SAML_KEYSTORE_PATH
items.description: The filesystem path to the keystore file containing the SP private key and any necessary public certificates to validate the IDP.

items.name: SAML_LOGIN_URL
items.description: If your IDP does not support SP-initiated SSO (very uncommon), you use a separate login URL, outside of Cloudera Manager. Provide that URL here so that Cloudera Manager can use it when a user needs to log in.

items.name: SAML_METADATA_PATH
items.displayName: Path to SAML IDP Metadata File
items.description: The filesystem path to the IDP metadata XML file.

items.name: SAML_OID_ROLE
items.displayName: SAML Attribute Identifier for User Role
items.description: The URN OID that will identify the user's role in the SAML attributes. Only has an effect when 'Attribute' based role assignment is used.

items.name: SAML_OID_USER
items.displayName: SAML Attribute Identifier for User ID
items.description: The URN OID that will identify the user's ID in the SAML attributes.

items.name: SAML_RESPONSE_BINDING
items.description: The SAML Binding format that the IDP is asked to use when sending authentication responses.

items.name: SAML_ROLE_MAP
items.description: The values that will appear in the SAML role attribute for each Cloudera Manager role. The first value corresponds to the Full Administrator role. The second value corresponds to the Read-Only role. The third value corresponds to the Limited Operator role. The fourth value corresponds to the Operator role. The fifth value corresponds to the Configurator role. The sixth value corresponds to the Cluster Administrator. The seventh value corresponds to the BDR Administrator. The eighth value corresponds to the Navigator Administrator. The ninth value corresponds to the User Administrator. The tenth value corresponds to the Auditor. The eleventh value corresponds to the Key Administrator.

items.name: SAML_ROLE_MAPPER
items.description: The mechanism to use for assigning roles to users. 'Attribute' assigns roles based on a SAML attribute. 'Script' assigns roles based on the result of an external script.

items.name: SAML_ROLE_SCRIPT
items.displayName: Path to SAML Role Assignment Script
items.description: An external script (or binary) to use to assign roles to SAML users. The username is passed as the first command-line argument. Program exit code should be: 0 for Full Administrator, 1 for Read-Only, 2 for Limited Operator, 3 for Operator, 4 for Configurator, 5 for Cluster Administrator, 6 for BDR Administrator, 7 for Navigator Administrator, 8 for User Administrator, 9 for Auditor, 10 for Key Administrator, and a negative value for failure.

items.name: SAML_USER_SOURCE

items.name: SCM_CONFIG_SUPPRESSION_TRUSTSTORE_PATH

items.name: SECURITY_REALM
items.description: The realm to use for Kerberos security. Note: Changing this setting would clear up all existing credentials and keytabs from Cloudera Manager.

items.name: SESSION_LIMIT_CONCURRENCY
items.displayName: Maximum Number of Active User Sessions
items.description: Restrict users to a certain number of active sessions at a time. If set, a user is limited to the specified number of sessions, and the oldest session is terminiated if the user logs in somewhere else. If not set, users can be logged in from as many places as they choose. If the user has 'Remember Me' turned on, or SAML is used for authentication, the user is automatically logged back in each time the session is ended. '0' means no limit is applied.

items.name: SESSION_REMEMBER_ME
items.description: Whether to allow a user to select 'Remember Me' when logging in. If this is set, the user will not need to log in again for two weeks (unless the server is restarted during that time). If the user chooses 'Remember Me', then the session timeout is ignored.

items.name: SESSION_TIMEOUT
items.description: The length of time a user's session can be idle for before the user must log in again. Note that currently logged in users will continue with their old timeout values.

items.name: SHOW_STACKTRACES
items.description: Control whether stacktraces are shown on error pages. While stacktraces help with debugging, they can sometimes expose sensitive information to a potentially malicious user.

items.name: SINGLE_USER_ENABLED
items.description: Configure all clusters to run in single user mode where the Cloudera Manager agent and all service processes run as the same system user. Only supported for CDH 5.2 and higher.

items.name: SINGLE_USER_GROUP
items.description: System group to use for agent and service processes in single user mode.

items.name: SINGLE_USER_NAME
items.description: System user to use for agent and service processes in single user mode.

items.name: SSL_CERTIFICATE_HOSTNAME
items.description: Host name associated with CM Server SSL certificate to be passed to configuration of newly added host as the host agents are to connect to.

items.name: SYSTEM_IDENTIFIER
items.description: An identifier for this system, to be included with diagnostic data bundles.

items.name: TRUSTED_REALMS
items.description: List of Kerberos realms that all services on this Cloudera Manager should trust. This parameter is used to configure and verify krb5.conf file. The parameter is auto-configured while adding a peer, but it is recommended that users ensure the values are correct.

items.name: TRUSTSTORE_PASSWORD
items.displayName: Cloudera Manager TLS/SSL Certificate Trust Store Password
items.description: The password for the Cloudera Manager TLS/SSL Certificate Trust Store File. This password is not required to access the trust store; this field can be left blank. This password provides optional integrity checking of the file. The contents of trust stores are certificates, and certificates are public information.

items.name: TRUSTSTORE_PATH
items.displayName: Cloudera Manager TLS/SSL Certificate Trust Store File
items.description: The location on disk of the trust store, in .jks format, used to confirm the authenticity of TLS/SSL servers that Cloudera Manager might connect to. This is used when Cloudera Manager is the client in a TLS/SSL connection. This trust store must contain the certificate(s) used to sign the service(s) connected to. If this parameter is not provided, the default list of well-known certificate authorities is used instead.

items.name: TSQUERY_HEATMAP_STREAMS_LIMIT
items.displayName: Maximum Number of Time-Series Streams Returned Per Heatmap
items.description: The maximum number of time-series streams returned by a single time-series heatmap query. The default is 10,000 streams. This value can be set higher, but increasing it may negatively impact chart performance and may require more resources be given to the Cloudera Manager Server, Host Monitor, and Service Monitor.

items.name: TSQUERY_SCATTER_STREAMS_LIMIT
items.displayName: Maximum Number of Time-Series Streams Returned Per Scatter Plot
items.description: The maximum number of time-series streams returned by a single time-series scatter plot. The default is 1000 streams. This value can be set higher, but increasing it may negatively impact chart performance and may require more resources be given to the Cloudera Manager Server, Host Monitor, and Service Monitor.

items.name: TSQUERY_STREAMS_LIMIT
items.displayName: Maximum Number Of Time-Series Streams Returned Per Line-Based Chart
items.description: The maximum number of time-series streams that will be returned by a single time-series query. The default is 250 streams. This value can be set higher, but increasing it may negatively impact chart performance and may require more resources be given to the Cloudera Manager Server, Host Monitor, and Service Monitor.

items.name: TSQUERY_TABLE_STREAMS_LIMIT
items.displayName: Maximum Number of Time-Series Streams Returned Per Table
items.description: The maximum number of time-series streams returned in a single time-series table. The default is 2000 streams. This value can be set higher, but increasing it may negatively impact chart performance and may require more resources be given to the Cloudera Manager Server, Host Monitor, and Service Monitor.

items.name: USING_HELP_FROM_CCP
items.displayName: Open latest Help files from the Cloudera website
items.description: If this option is selected, the Help link opens the latest Help files from the Cloudera web site (requires Internet access from the browser). If not selected, the locally installed Help files, which are not updated after installation, are opened (no Internet access from the browser is required).

items.name: WEB_TLS
items.displayName: Use TLS Encryption for Admin Console
items.description: Enable TLS encryption (HTTPS) between the user and the Cloudera Manager Admin Console. When checked, the HTTPS port will be used.
